author: Vitamin Daily
title: A Fresh Take on Calgary
text: 7 Spectacular Alberta Road Trips of   Exploring the Canadian Badlands is your chance to walk in the footsteps of the dinosaurs. Check out petroglyphs, fossils, and the natural rock formations of the hoodoos. (Pictured: Writing-on-Stone Provincial Park) Distance: Approximately 170 kilometres round-trip. (Pictured: A hoodoo in the Canadian Badlands) The Royal Tyrrell Museum is just one of the fascinating stops on this drive, and features 35 dinosaur skeletons, as well as interpretive galleries to educate visitors about prehistoric life in Canada. There are also several walking paths nearby to explore the unique rock formations in this stunning part of Alberta. (Pictured: Hoodoos near the Royal Tyrrell Museum) As you explore Midland Provincal Park, take time for a picnic lunch and an opportunity to stretch your legs at Horsethief Canyon and Orkney Hills. Or you can swing over to neighbouring Dinosaur Provincial Park (pictured) for a beautiful hike. Other sights to see and experience: - The Rosedale Suspension Bridge - The Atlas Coal Mine National Historic Site - Last Chance Saloon in Wayne, Alta. If you're making the trek from Calgary to Edmonton this summer, why not get off the beaten path and take the long way around? Instead of travelling the TransCanada, explore the rich history of Hwy. 21 and 56. (Pictured: A train runs by a canola field on Hwy. 21) Distance: Approximately 357 km (Picture: Bassano) One of the highlights of the Boomtown Trail is stunning Buffalo Lake, which provides warm enough summer waters for a refreshing dip, or a gorgeous sunset later in the day. (Pictured: Buffalo Lake) At the Anthony Henday Museum in Delburn, you can check out a replica pioneer cabin and former railway water tower with four floors of exhibits. Other sights to see and experience: - The Big Valley Jamboree in Camrose (July 30- Aug. 2) - The world's largest collection of road lamps in Donalda - The Canadian Railway Hall of Fame The Iron Horse Trail follows Alberta’s northeastern Lakeland district along the rail lines abandoned by the Canadian National Railway in 1999. It's a haven for outdoor recreation enthusiasts, with wetlands, rolling hills, lakes and forest. There are also plenty of quaint towns and villages along the way, with lots of northern Alberta culture to be found. Distance: Approximately 191 km from Waskatenau to Cold Lake and approximately 177 km from Waskatenau to Heinsburg (Pictured: An wheat field in Smoky Lake) Ashmont, one of the small villages along the trail, hosts a major equestrian staging area and is an excellent starting point for trail riding. Other sights to see and experience: - Take in the scenery of White Earth Valley and its numerous trestles over the White Earth River - From Waskatenau, bike along the historic Victoria Trail to stop at the RCMP memorial commemorating the arrival of the NWMP in Alberta in 1874 - Take the northeast fork all the way to Cold Lake for a trail hike and a picnic (Pictured: Cold Lake, Alta.) The Icefields Parkway is one of Alberta's, and perhaps Canada's, most scenic and majestic drives. The twisty road takes you high and low through the peaks and valleys of the Alberta Rockies, passing awe-inspiring glaciers and pristine mountain lakes just steps from the road. Distance: Approximately 232 km from Lake Louise to Jasper It wouldn't be a tour of the Icefields Parkway without a stop at the Columbia Icefield. Walk on a glacier or take an Ice Explorer bus for a guided tour of the Athabasca Glacier, where the ice is as thick as the Eiffel Tower is tall! Wildlife is a frequent sight on the Icefields Parkway, and man and animal often cross paths. Dawn and dusk are the best times for animal sightings. Other sights to see and experience: - Make time for a hike at Patricia Lake, Peyto Lake or Lake Louise - Stop in at Athabasca Falls near Jasper to witness the incredible churning water and canyon - Bring your tent for an overnight adventure at one of the area's many campgrounds (Pictured: Patricia Lake) There's nowhere better in Alberta to get in touch with your cowboy or cowgirl roots than along the Cowboy Trail. It's a place to travel back in time to the heart of the old west, where ranchlands meet the foothills of the Canadian Rockies. Distance: Approximately 105 km from Cochrane to Longview In need of a snack and a place to put up your boots? The Longview Jerky Shop in Longview makes their own jerky in-house and is a must visit on your travels. The Turner Valley Gas Plant National and Provincial Historic Site is the most significant surviving resource associated with the development of the Turner Valley oilfield. The Dingman No. 1. oil well ushered in Alberta's first oil boom. Other sights to see and experience: - Stop at MacKay's Ice Cream in Cochrane for some of the best ice cream in the province - Make the drive over to The Bar U Ranch National Historic Site for a tour in a horse-drawn wagon - Take in the scenery at Chain Lake Provincial Park If you're B.C. bound via southern Alberta, you won't want to miss the historic drive through the Crownest Pass. You'll find an area rich with mining history, a devastating rock slide, and plenty of panoramic mountain vistas. Distance: Approximately 95 km from Fort Macleod to Coleman One of the first stops you'll come across on the Crowsnest Trail is the site of Frank Slide. In 1903, the face of Turtle Mountain came off, sending 82 million tonnes of rock down, which partially covered the town of Frank. An interpretive centre now tells the story of those who lived and those who died in this powerful act of nature. The five historic towns of Bellevue, Hillcrest, Frank, Blairmore and Coleman tell the story of coal mining in Alberta, and feature plenty of historic hikes and cozy places to grab a cup of coffee or a plate of comfort food. (Picture: Coleman, Alta.) Other sights to see and experience: - Take an interpretive tour of the Leitch Collieries -- one of Alberta's biggest mining operations at the turn of the 20th century - Stop for a photo at the Burmis Tree, said to be the most photographed tree in Canada - Pay your respects at the Hillcrest Mine, where 189 men died in 1914, making it the worst mining disaster in Canadian history (Pictured: The Burmis Tree) Kananaskis is one of those place in Alberta where the locals go to enjoy all the activities that tourists flock to try in the national parks. Kananaskis is considerably more quiet than Banff or Jasper, but still holds plenty of opportunity to hike, swim, kayak, canoe or just spend some quiet time in nature. (Pictured: Kananaskis Country Golf Course) Distance: Approximately 300 km round trip (Pictured: Kananaskis Lake) You won't find many towns or tourism outfitters in Kananaskis country, but you will find plenty of breathtaking scenery. Plan ahead and bring your own canoe, kayak, or even just your hiking boots, and choose your own adventure. (Picture: The Widow Maker) Always be bear aware in this part of Alberta -- in fact, be on the lookout for all different species of wildlife. Other sights to see and experience: - Take the easy 10 kilometre hike around Barrier Lake - Have lunch in Kananaskis village and go for a walk around town - Grab some clubs at hit up the nine-hole LivingStone Golf Course  Share
